Abstract:
Fast and accurate prediction of extreme climate events is critical, especially in the current globally warming environment. Given recent advancements in deep neural networks, it is worthwhile to tackle this problem using data-driven spatio-temporal prediction. However, a non-trivial challenge lies in irregular time gaps between climate observation data due to sensor errors and other issues. This paper proposes an approach for spatio-temporal hurricane prediction that addresses this issue with a simple yet robust end-to-end model based on Neural Ordinary Differential Equations and a video prediction model based on Retrospective Cycle GAN.

Introduction:
Predicting extreme climate events is a pressing and challenging problem that humanity faces. Global warming is changing the mechanism and life cycle of extreme climate events, making it increasingly frequent and rapid (Emanuel, 2017; Mousavi et al., 2011; Pielke Jr et al., 2005; Schulthess et al., 2018). To understand dynamics of extreme climate events accurately and quickly, it is essential to develop a reliable prediction method. Traditionally, physics-based simulations have been used to predict extreme climate events, producing high-resolution data that enables exploration of future scenarios. However, applying conventional simulation-based methods at a large scale is challenging, as it requires exascale computing even at moderate resolution (Hardiker, 1997; Vetter, 2019). Moreover, global climate data from simulations makes identification and quantitative assessment of extreme climate events difficult, especially when events are locally nested in a small region of space and time, such as a hurricane.

Thanks to the development of deep learning, the climate research community has made significant progress in developing models to solve the spatio-temporal nowcasting problem of climate events using various neural network models (Shi et al., 2017; 2015; Agrawal et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2017; Kim et al., 2019a; b). Considering temporal dynamics of climate patterns, most existing approaches formulate climate nowcasting as a video prediction problem and apply recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to predict the next timestep based on previous timesteps (Shi et al., 2017; 2015; Kim et al., 2019b; a). However, RNN-based models have a serious drawback in climate event nowcasting, as they assume regular time steps between adjacent time steps, which is not often the case with climate data. Climate data are measured intermittently (e.g., for hours), but we often want to predict in finer temporal resolution for nowcasting. Observations are frequently missing, making it non-trivial to apply vanilla RNN models to this problem. Moreover, longer-term prediction is extremely challenging with a naive RNN-based model, as the quality of prediction in test-time is gradually degraded along the prediction time.

To address these challenges in physics-based and RNN-based methods, we propose a Neural-ODE-based hurricane nowcasting model that is (1) computationally more efficient and (2) can handle input and output with irregular time steps. Neural ODE (Ordinary Differential Equations) (Chen et al., 2018) is a recently proposed model that can learn the representation of an irregularly sampled sequence data. Specifically, it parameterizes the derivative of the hidden state using a neural network instead of specifying a discrete sequence of hidden layers. The output of the network is computed using a differential equation solver. To elaborate the capability of Neural ODE to learn and predict data with irregular time steps, our proposed model combines Neural ODE with a video prediction model in an end-to-end manner.

The contribution of the proposed model lies in the unified framework for tackling the extreme climate nowcasting problem with irregular time steps using Neural ODE and video prediction technique, which can be trained end-to-end. The main contributions are:

* Continuous timestep prediction: Guided by the motion information of the hurricane at an arbitrary time point in the future predicted by Neural-ODE, our proposed model can deal with climate data with irregular time steps. Specifically, our model can predict future frames after an arbitrary timestep given input with irregular timesteps.
* Computationally efficient: In the trade-off between computational cost and accuracy, our proposed model is more efficient than traditional methods.
